messageBody:
Very interesting.  Thanks, John, for the history lesson.

I was thinking of Henry the VIII's reign and the lack of standardization at that time.  You are suggesting that the standards had firmed up considerably in the latter part of the 16th century.  Was the chaos of private spelling, as you refer to it, difficult to comprehend, or did it just slow reading down because one was forced to decipher unusually spelled words too frequently?

It makes sense that professional scribes would tend toward standardization.  Since they spent their working lives writing, they would be likely to develop spellings that were consistent over time.  Of course, I would suspect that a large part of the spelling inconsistencies prior to this had to do with the poor fit between the Roman alphabet and English phonemes.  It would not be possible to spell words in so many different ways if the alphabet fit English better as QS does. 

The bare statement that the official Dutch orthography changes every few decades implies that some organization with authority makes that change.  What is that organization?  The Dutch government?  A language academy?  It appears to me that standardized does mean "fixed" in English because there is no authority to force a change on a language spoken around the world.

I am not advocating anarchy in spelling -- just some freedom for individuality.  I believe that the percentage of words which people would spell differently would be relatively limited and would not greatly impede readability.

Paige

P.S.  Moira, thanks for your input.

John Cowan wrote:

pgabhart scripsit:
> When Shakespeare was penning his plays, I believe standardized spelling
> was a concept that did not exist.

It most definitely did. The First Folio's spelling is nowhere near
as standardized as any modern work, but it is far from the chaos of
private spelling in the early 17th century. Scribes and scriveners
(professional letter-writers for the illiterate) had been converging on
a standard spelling of late Middle and early Modern English since 1422,
when the Brewers Company (a guild) first started to issue their records
in English. Before the Norman Conquest, there had been a similarly
standardized spelling of Old English, some of which persisted into
early Middle English times. When Tolkien was not writing about elves
and hobbits, one of the things he did was to discover that the various
manuscripts of an early 13th-century work called the _Ancrene Wisse_,
though in different handwritings, had extremely consistent spellings
and dialect markers, showing that the various scribes had learned how
to spell English in a school of some sort, a good two centuries after
the Norman Conquest had supposedly sent English underground.

> Nevertheless, the fact that publishers "want" a standardized spelling
> has more to do with tradition than necessity I expect.

Of the written languages of the world (most are unwritten), many lack a
standard orthography: Cherokee is an example. But as far as is known,
every language where literacy is widespread and there is no competing
written language commonly used (Cherokee records, after all, are mostly
in English) has converged on a common standard or a few standards.
And no language has ever reverted in its public written works to
unstandardized spelling.

> Once a spelling is "fixed," no one has the authority to change it in the
> future.

Standardized doesn't mean fixed. The official Dutch orthography changes
every few decades.

> Another issue is involves the changes the publishing industry will
> undergo in the future. Before long, it may be that books will be
> printed as the demand calls for them, and the concept of a first
> printing of a certain number of copies may disappear from the industry
> altogether.

Print-on-demand doesn't affect the fundamental division between edited
and unedited works. It's true that there is much more unedited publicly
available work than ever before.

And multiple standards with automatic conversion will *depend* on the
existence of an internationalized base version, because no individual
accent continues to make all the distinctions that, collectively, all
accents make.
